data.title: TL:DR (That's Long, DID Read)
data.text:
Between the ages of 19 and 21, I wrote a series of notes (the longest is about a page, so somewhere between a sketch and a mini-essay I guess) that made up a kind of summary of my worldview at the time. At this point I donâ€™t remember why I wrote them, but Iâ€™m sure it wasnâ€™t for its own sake; they were probably things that were to be â€œboiled downâ€ and processed and incorporated somehow into poetry, strange though that sounds. From an early age, I always wanted to write. The first things I remember voluntarily writing are simplified versions of the kind of fantasy gamebooks that were then hugely popular with kids. The Swords & Sorcery series (more about that by one of the other authors of the series here) emulated Steve Jackson and Ian Livinstoneâ€™s Fighting Fantasy single-player role-playing game books pretty shamelessly but were a lot of (complicated) fun to write, though few of them were actually finished. These were followed by (and/or parallel to) various short horror stories, but in the long adolescence that seems to have lasted in my case from 15 until 25 or so, I mostly wrote poetry. Itâ€™s fair to say that it was not good.

The notes though, are fun.

They cover a range of topics â€“ politics, religion, aesthetics, social issues, ecology, the monarchy â€“ and are exceptionally embarrassing to read. But interesting too, because although I do of course remember being 19-21, I otherwise only have the distorting mirror of my own memory to go by, and my own taste in music, books etc, which give a kind of connection to ur-me. But these notes are pretty much what I thought, expressed to the best of my ability (or thereabouts). They reveal some interesting things I had not realised about my younger self. Although I generally did fairly well in English at school, I now see that my spelling was quite erratic (especially on words ending in -itely, which I always wanted to make -ately, like â€˜definatelyâ€™) and that I must not have learned the itâ€™s/its rule until later. The pieces are typed, on an actual typewriter as I didnâ€™t own a computer at the time, which was not actually all that strange then. More to the point though, by that age my always-terrible handwriting had deteriorated to the point where I myself found it hard to read things I had written after any length of time had lapsed. The socio-political/geographical background to the notes was the bitter, tail end of the UKâ€™s thousand year Tory Reich that I grew up in. Thatcher had by then gone, but the evolution/mutation into the Major era had made very little difference, except insofar as John Major himself was vastly inferior as a hate figure than Thatcher had been.

Itâ€™s funny; the arrogance and certainty of youth is well-known, but I am very surprised to find it in myself. I have rarely met anyone less sure of themselves or more reticent than my late-teens/early-20s self, but that doesnâ€™t really come across at all, except in a few deliberately self-deprecating caveats, and thereâ€™s an infuriating cockiness to some of the writing that I not only donâ€™t identify with, but really detest; whatâ€™s mortifying is that I was genuinely trying to think deeply about the issues I covered so shallowly. Oh well, I hope I wasnâ€™t actually that obnoxious in everyday life, but who knows? (anyone who knew me). On the other hand, my actual views donâ€™t seem to have changed as much as I would have expected. I was more of a libertarian, albeit a left-wing one then, perhaps a bit more pessimistic, but on the whole I would still find myself on the same side of most of the arguments I am making, which is reassuring.

I donâ€™t intend to transcribe very much of the writing here because I canâ€™t bear to, mostly, but hereâ€™s a synopsis of the contents of the documents and there will be a couple of more extended examples below that illustrate how much/little/comically times have changed since then (the mid-1990s)

I donâ€™t know if these were ever in any order, but hereâ€™s what I have:

â€œClassic Mythsâ€ â€“ examining, in very little depth or detail, how things become â€œclassics.â€ It ends with the question (re. literature) â€œhow many great works have disappeared into the mists of time due to personal taste or political, religeous [sic] or moral qualms on the part of the academics of the past?â€ At this point I was reading the long out-of-fashion (and out of print) poetry of Robert Southey which was, to be honest mostly pretty hard going â€“ but I was determined to like his early, pro-revolutionary work from his â€˜Pantisocracyâ€™ days with Coleridge, and I did, when I could find it anywhere.

â€œThe Eye of the Beholder â€“ Oneâ€ This was me complaining about how Hollywood/popular culture/fashion were making standards of beauty ever more bland in a diminishing returns/vicious circle kind of way. Its exceptionally snooty tone was coloured by the fact that I was discovering the movies of the silent and pre-Hays code era and my own personal objects of desire were people like Louise Brooks, Joan Blondell and Marlene Dietrich. Sample of tone: â€œSadly this means that when a certain actor or actress is in a hit film, similar actors and actresses will appear in similar films and so on and on, to ever-diminishing effect, until a new trend (snowboarding and dark hair, perhaps) transforms the screen for a few months or weeks(â€¦) this ever-growing supply and demand for something familiar makes it hard for original voices to be heard, or any kind of innovation or talent to gain an audience.â€ ğŸ˜¬

â€œReligion Crazyâ€ â€“ This is pretty much what youâ€™d expect from an atheist teenager, full of such blinding revelations as â€œReligion has often looked to me like a cunning scheme invented by some ancient tyrant to keep the peasants in their placeâ€ and, even better, â€œintolerance of religion and the religious is a vice I magnanimously allow myself to indulge in.â€ My own lack of belief hasnâ€™t changed in the slightest since the days when I used to look around the room during the morning recitation of the Lordâ€™s Prayer at Primary School, to see who else had their eyes open. But I though I donâ€™t necessarily disagree with him (and actually am him), I donâ€™t really feel much kinship with the writer of these lines, or especially his tone, now: â€œAm I to believe in a petty, small-minded god who creates something only to punish and destroy it? Maybe in a bored or indifferent god, as is suggested by its (had to correct it, sorry) conspicuous absence in the last few centuries. Perhaps it is more interested in ants than people, and appears to them all the the time.â€

â€œSexuality and Childrenâ€ Luckily I was aware even then that this was an alarming and â€œrather dodgyâ€ title, but essentially it was about the debate then ongoing about gay parents adopting children. My attitude (as with many of my then-attitudes) was essentially a slightly shaky but very teenage libertarian one: who is entitled to tell other adults how to live their lives? â€œAside from (fairly ridiculous) superstitious quibbles which can be disregarded at once, (by me anyway) there is no reason on Earth why it is the business of any but those directly involved.â€ I still think the same thing, more or less but again the tone is, to be kind, insufferably annoying.

â€œNot Winning isnâ€™t Losingâ€ â€“ politics, kind of. Contains nuggets like â€œMy ideal political situation is unworkable (â€¦) (it) amounts to well behaved anarchy.â€ But again, I still believe parts of it, despite painfully naive bits, like â€œThe impossibility of a left-wing political ideal does not mean it is hopeless â€“ indeed the opposite is true. Because it can never be attained, there would always be a working towards it â€“ the lack of destination would improve the journey. The effect of a constant working towards a state of freedom and equality would inevitably lead to and ever-improving state of more freedom and more equality â€“ which can not be bad.â€

â€œBooksâ€ â€“ this is funny, so Iâ€™ll write about it in more depth later

â€œPower Crazedâ€ This is one single line, which I hope isnâ€™t true: â€œThere can never be a good Prime Minister, because Prime Ministers are people whose ambition is to rule the country.â€

â€œLimitsâ€ â€“ an excruciating piece about nationalism/patriotism and so forth, in which our author pompously concludes â€œAs far as Iâ€™m concerned, I find it absolutely impossible to feel either proud or ashamed of anything that occurred completely beyond my control â€“ race, sex (I guess I meant as in gender), sexuality â€“ or where I was born.â€

â€œMoneyâ€ â€“ a blindingly obvious revelation that the idea of money is, when you look at it, kind of silly. â€œWhy is gold a valuable metal? Presumably because it looks nicer than other metals, and there is less of it.â€ etc, etc

â€œTripping on the Catwalkâ€ In which I make my ignorance about the fashion industry obvious, and which includes the bizarre statement that â€œits nearest relative is perhaps the academic world of the university. It is completely self supporting, untouched by recession, mainly due to the fact that it is run by bored rich people for bored rich people.â€ I am now fairly sure that this isnâ€™t 100% true. I also predicted â€œan eighties-style big shoulders revival (though with a nineties twist of course) before the turn of the millennium.â€ I donâ€™t remember if that happened or not, but itâ€™s happened since then.

â€œRoyalty at the End of the Millenniumâ€ â€“ Oddly, this is one of the longer pieces. As itâ€™s as topical in the new reign of Charles III as it was then (?) Iâ€™ll deal with it later

â€œPart(l)y Politics Oneâ€ Despite the parenthetical â€˜lâ€™ this is pretty much about party politics. In short; the Conservative Party is contemptible (â€œI have to assume some right-wingers are intelligent, though I have seen little evidence of thisâ€). But I also seem to be saying that because conservatism is based on the fear of change and the desire for stability, plus an array of standard human failings; ignorance, fear, confusion, greed etc, it will always appeal to a large part of the population.

I theorise, not entirely inaccurately, about a pattern that I hadnâ€™t then seen in action and which I later saw parts of in action â€“ because Conservative governments appeal to the worst in people, they REALLY have to mess up before they get voted out. So therefore, any prospective left-wing government will spend a good deal of time un-wrecking the country, with consequent hardships. The public and opposition will naturally blame those in charge for those hardships, the problem then becomes that a progressive party gets voted out, but the incumbent right wing party inherits a country on the mend, which they take credit for, before ruining everything again. Thatâ€™s not exactly how Tories â€“ Labour â€“ Tories played out in our time but it still feels plausible and at least not untrue.

â€œinterludeâ€ â€“ between the two â€œPart(l)y Politicsâ€ pieces thereâ€™s a short kind of non sequitur in which I claim that the politics of the left, taken to their furthest extreme (i.e. ideologically, rather than in real life) is â€œa nice, if unworkable idea based on equality and human rightsâ€ while the politics of the right taken to their furthest extreme is â€at best an extremely nasty and distressingly workable idea based on hatred, repression and manipulation.â€ Not sure I agree with either of those statements now, though I think my heart was in the right place.

â€œPart(l)y Politics Twoâ€ â€“ in which I complain that the Labour Party (and by extension any party of â€œthe workersâ€ is hopelessly compromised by a system in which becoming an MP is an ordinary middle class career choice, rather than being a kind of glorified shop steward. This was the Neil Kinnock/John Smith/Margaret Beckett era and I complain about the same thing that every Labour-voter-by-default has complained about ever since: that Labour in opposition try too hard to be all things to all people, appeal to Tory voters, are middle-of-the-road and inoffensive rather than truly progressive etc. Itâ€™s all very pessimistic: â€œWe can only hope that this [middle-of-the-road inoffensiveness] is a sort of ruse to gain power, whereupon the new and hopefully forceful, idea-led Labour Party will throw off its current greyness, the spectre of past success and failure and emerge as a strong socialist party for the twenty-first century (â€¦) The conservatives â€˜accuseâ€™ the Labour Party of being the same old socialist party underneath. This seems sadly unlikely â€“ we understand socialism to be a system based on fairer distribution of wealth and of equality etc etc â€“ the Labour Party does not seem to be offering this. We will vote for them, because there is no one else to vote for.â€

â€œOpposites Attractâ€ â€“ this is a self-pitying whine about how â€œthe plain or ugly are naturally attracted to the good looking, the handsome, the beautiful. The good looking, the handsome and the beautiful are naturally attracted to the good looking, the handsome, the beautiful. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder, but few beholdersâ€™ eyes will want to linger very long on the truly unattractive person.â€ I actually wrote this stuff down.

â€œInhumanityâ€ Here it is: â€œâ€™Manâ€™s inhumanity to manâ€™ is a phrase used to describe acts which are definingly human. What other species would (or could) have had the atomic bomb, or the holocaust? It is a deceptive and cowardly phrase.â€ Well alright then.

â€œFood Philistineâ€ â€“ A strange and very silly short piece in which I discover that my attitude to food (though I had â€œno aversion to itâ€) was â€œthe same as my attitude to sleep â€“ if I could do without it, I would.â€ I donâ€™t feel that way about either food or sleep now, really and until now I didnâ€™t realise I had ever felt that way.

â€œMoney, money, moneyâ€ In short, class = wealth. The problem with Britain is (I seem to be saying) that the upper class control the wealth of the working class while the complacent middle class are indifferent as long as they are comfortable & therefore provide the upper class with a comfortable mattress to insulate them from the should-be-revolutionary consequences of their greed. It may be true?

â€œThe Eye of the Beholder Twoâ€ â€“ this time itâ€™s all about how I prefer brutalist architecture to old churches etc and prefer the â€œdrab emptinessâ€ of municipal parks, deserted backstreets etc to epic, panoramic landscapes. Nowadays I like all of those things.

â€œResponsibilityâ€ A â€œpro choiceâ€ rant that, Iâ€™m glad but surprised to say, reads exactly like the social media posts of â€˜pro choiceâ€™ people in the last few years â€“ it begins â€œThe anti-abortion lobby, for all their rhetoric about the sanctity of human life, seem to disregard entirely (and with great relish) the quality of human life. Indeed, they seem to enjoy inflicting misery wherever they go.â€ And it ends with the even more 2020s-ish: â€œTo the anti-abortionist, the human being is only a human being until it is born. After that it is not their problem.â€ I was right then and still am now: yay me.

â€œCensoredâ€ In which I get on my high horse about the right to watch violent horror movies: â€œWhen I hear that a member of the British Board of Film Classification has embarked on an orgy of violence and mayhem using a chainsaw, I will begin to believe that film violence has an effect on the viewer (if it happens twice.)â€ I DO think it has an effect on the viewer â€“ actually, I hope it does, or why even bother? Disturbing things should be disturbing. But my views on censorship (if no harm is done in the making of it then who has the right to say an adult shouldnâ€™t watch it) are pretty much the same. I probably believe in â€˜classificationâ€™ and parental responsibility more now than I did then though.

â€œA Fair Dayâ€™s Payâ€¦â€ Manual workers should be at the top of the pay pyramid as their work is harder and more necessary, but pen pushers are in charge of wages etc so itâ€™ll never happen, he seems to be saying.

â€œAnimalsâ€ A very dubious piece in which I query the relative value of human beings and other animals, slightly in favour of other animals, or at least not in favour of us humans.

â€œPower Corrupts â€“ Small timeâ€ â€œPower corrupts â€“ this is an indisputable fact,â€ I say â€“ but is it? Anyway, my premise is that dictators are bad and all, but for really corrupt power you have to look at school teachers and small-town police officers.

â€œGrown Men and Womenâ€ â€“ Me, moaning about sport

â€œHow to Spoke Properâ€ â€“ In short,â€œspeaking properlyâ€ (in the UK sense) is a classist fantasy based on the random fact that the BBC happened to be founded in the south of England. This may or may not be true.

â€œRules of Attractionâ€ â€“ â€œSexuality has nothing to do with morality,â€ he says, â€œI am attracted to members of the opposite sex because I was born this way â€“ so if I saw a member of my own sex who looked like a member of the opposite sex in a way that I found attractive, I would naturally be attracted to them, for as long as they looked like an attractive female. I do not see how there can be anything wrong with this, or any variation of it.â€ This sounds like an argument with some lurking real-life subtext, but to the best of my knowledge now, it wasnâ€™t.

â€œThe Seaâ€ â€“ itâ€™s about the sea, which I apparently felt very strongly about. I still love the sea but canâ€™t imagine writing very emotionally about it.

â€œPhilosophyâ€ â€“ As an atheist is there any more logical philosophy than to live a life of pure hedonism? I seem to conclude not, but for me at the time this was a purely hypothetical question

â€œAgainst Natureâ€ â€“ Here it is in full: â€œHumankind is natural, as much a part of nature as anything else on the planet. Everything humankind does is natural. The worst it can do (selfishly speaking) is to kill itself off, which in a universal sense, would be no big loss.â€ I was in some ways a very standard teenager I guess. Joy Division was probably my favourite band at that point

So, here are the more extended bits.

Firstly, Iâ€™ve chosen â€œBooksâ€ because it is the one that most amusingly makes the 1990s seem like it was a million years ago. My main argument is that though people were (as they always seem to have been) predicting the death of the printed word, books are unlikely to be replaced by anything else. But let young Will explain it, as his Nostradamus-like powers of prediction donâ€™t seem to have anticipated the Kindle. More strangely, he does not seem to be aware of laptops, didnâ€™t they already exist in the mid-90s? Surely! To be fair to him though, â€œweâ€ still prefer a book to a kindle or tablet which I canâ€™t stand using unless itâ€™s the only way to read something.

Anyway, the death of books will not happen, he says, becauseâ€¦

â€œThey are convenient, we [he often calls himself â€˜weâ€™] cannot imagine taking even a small computer on a train or plane, or to the beach or on holiday in our suitcase â€“ though this may be possible in the future. We like to go back a page and reread something, whilst[!] keeping our place on the page we have reached. We like the thought, whether we actually do it or not, of being able to read Wordsworth in the mountains of the Lake District â€“ we feel that a keyboard and a screen would take away a rather large part of the romance of this.â€

â€œRoyalty at the End of the Millenniumâ€ is fun because itâ€™s surprisingly still topical (up to a point) and begins by saying things, far more grumpily, that I probably still think. Iâ€™ll transcribe as much of it as I can bear, with the faulty punctuation and repetition intact because the tediousness is part of the fun. Still, itâ€™s odd and a bit alarming to find a UKIP-ish tone intruding re. the funding of the Royal family, even if I thought I was playing Devilâ€™s avocado (as I might have said) at the time.

â€œWhy do (how can) people like the Royal Family? I donâ€™t know. What is even stranger than this affection is the public liking one member of the family, and (apparently randomly) not another. â€˜Fergieâ€™ seems to be disliked for acting like any normal person suddenly coming into a huge amount of money i.e. spending it. People who claim to dislike her because of affairs etc seem to forget or dismiss the affairs of (practically all) other family members.

People liking (or even loving) Princess Diana is one of the biggest mysteries of our age. The myth of Diana as a beautiful woman started before the Royal Wedding and continue to this day. Are these people blind? Do they really believe it? Are they just trying to sell newspapers or cash in on Royal memorabilia? Who knows? The fact is that she is an average, ordinary-looking woman in her thirties with a large nose, large chin, and even larger amount of money to make the most of what she has with.* (The reader may be forgiven for assuming that the writer of these words must be very handsome, to stand in judgement of other peoples looks â€“ this is certainly not the case â€“ but I do not have a media conspiracy trying to convince people that I am).

More seriously (and it is a serious matter when a country is in a serious[!] recession, and yet itâ€™s people give millions of pounds a year to keep one family in, well, the lap of luxury would be a gross understatement â€“ especially when this one family already has millions of pounds of inherited private wealth). What are the reasons for and against the Royal Family?

Well, the for argument usually falls into two compartments[?] â€“ tradition, and (feebly) that the Royals are good for the economy via the tourist trade. The first of these is the stronger of the two and yet doesnâ€™t really bear close inspection â€“ is it necessarily good because itâ€™s traditional? Yes, the family is descended from a long line of noble (i.e. rich) families â€“ but they are not necessarily British families. They are Greek, they are German, but there is not an awful lot of British blood in there. As far as I am concerned, this would not matter, except that the arguments for usually draw attention to it being a great British tradition, or institution. I can only say that itâ€™s not much of a native tradition that has the British public paying money to a European family to make them even richer.â€

Some more highlights â€“ this is just too tedious to write out in full:

â€œThere are few things as irritating as hearing how hard the Queen works â€“ give me a few million pounds a year and I will be glad to attend dinners, meet dignitaries and travel abroad â€“ not many people would turn down an offer like this.â€

â€œThe arguments against are much easier to state â€“ they donâ€™t do anything, we pay for them for being related to people, they are a British tradition which involves few British people, they could exist in comfort without public money, they represent an outdated (and according to the Prime Minister) non-existant class system, they stagger from one scandal to another and in a country with an underfunded health service, underfunded system of education, a large homeless population and mentally ill people being turned out onto the streets** they are a mockery of and insult to our supposedly democratic society.â€

So there we have it, an unexpected meeting with my apparently slightly intense, smart-assed but ridiculous younger self. Nice to catch up but Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™d want to hang out with him!

*Yes, I genuinely wrote â€œto make the most of what she has withâ€

**I assume this has something to do with the â€œcare in the communityâ€ scandal that seemed to be unfolding during the last few years of the Thatcher/Major era

The correct response to the title here is of course it depends who you are and what you did. But anyway; in a February when the big news story was the alarming spread of coronavirus/COVID-19, which history will tell us is either â€“ (a) a pandemic like none seen since the 1918 flu outbreak which killed between 20 and 50 million people (quite a big â€˜betweenâ€™. that) or (b) an unfortunate but quite normal kind of illness which is causing inconvenience and a certain amount of tragedy but is mainly a media frenzy like SARS or Bird Flu, and will blow over soon â€“ it seems a bit like fiddling while Rome burns to talk about music and books etc. But as everyone knows, Nero didnâ€™t really fiddle while Rome burned, and anyway, the big and relatively thoughtful thing I was writing during the Christmas holidays is no further forward and I mainly spent February writing things for other places than my own website, so there it is.

I just finished reading the newest edition* of Jon Savageâ€™s brilliant Englandâ€™s Dreaming which is as good as any music-related book Iâ€™ve ever read and made me realise how many parallels there are between now and the political situation in mid-70s Britain. Up to a point, that is. It would be hard, even I think for a conservative person, to see the victory of Johnsonâ€™s Tories as a return to some kind of sensible order in the way that deluded right wingers saw Thatcherâ€™s victory â€“ which did, it has to be said, render somewhat pointless the extreme right wing groups like the National Front & British Movement that had been growing in strength and influence throughout the decade. As with Johnson/the ERG and their wooing of the UKIP/nazi fanbase though, the reassurance that comes from seeing extremist groups losing popularity is soured (to put it mildly) by having people in charge who appeal to that demographic.

*the latest revised edition is from 2005, and is the one to get â€“ the excellent introduction, which addresses the â€˜Englishnessâ€™ of punk within the wider UK setting, is itself quite dated, though more relevant than ever, and this version also contains a brief summary of that most surprising part of the whole Sex Pistols story â€“ the bandâ€™s 1996 reunion.

Reading about punk â€“ especially remembering the very tail end of it in the early 80s (i.e. seeing the stereotypical 80s fashion punks and skinheads and reading THE EXPLOITED/OI!/PUNKS NOT DEAD etc spray painted all over the place) itâ€™s hard to imagine the force the movement had in â€™76-7. In my own era, Acid House/rave culture/etc has had an even bigger impact on music and arguably a comparable one culturally, but although it annoyed grownups and upset politicians it was never as deliberately confrontational or as alien and ugly as punk. Its figureheads, insofar as it had any, could certainly be â€˜outrageousâ€™ in a way, but Shaun Ryder and Bez swearing on TV was worlds away from the omnipresence of the Sex Pistols in the UK media of the 70s; not least because the Sex Pistols and punk had already happened. Pop stars being obnoxious in the 90s was not a phenomenon â€“ and the Pistols, despite everything, were a recognisable thing â€“ a pop group or rock band.

The public and the tabloids knew about the existence of acid house, and might be alarmed by the â€˜acidâ€™ aspect in particular â€“ but as far as signing record contracts, being on TV or playing concerts went, there wasnâ€™t much to report on. An interesting thing about the acid house/rave phenomenon was that, although a musical movement, the music and its makers barely featured in the moral panics that ensued, it was all about the audience. Whether this made it more frightening to the older generation, I donâ€™t know. In the 60s, the Woodstock kids might have been seen as outrageous dirty, drug taking hippies, but maybe the fact that they were being â€˜incitedâ€™ by Jimi Hendrix, The Who, Country Joe etc in a field (much like the teenagers in the 50s were under the influence of Bill Haley/Elvis etc and punk kids in the streets were being led astray by Rotten & co on TV) gave a clear them/us or leader/followers divide and made it easier to condemn/contain/control them? This is an interesting thing that I should think about more â€“ except that Iâ€™m almost certain that there will be a book out there by someone who has thought about it more and knows a lot more than I do about the 90s (the most I can say is â€˜I was thereâ€™, I wasnâ€™t mostly very interested in acid house etc at the time).

Anyway; certainly the punks were heirs to the hippies (not that they would have welcomed the comparison) in that the visibility of the punk audience (who, whatever their claims of individuality, were clearly â€“ especially by 1977 â€“ dressing in emulation of other punks, of whom Johnny Rotten was the most visible example) marked them out as â€˜otherâ€™. And made them a target of the authorities, as well as a flag for disaffected kids to rally to. The subtitle of Englandâ€™s Dreaming â€“ â€œThe Sex Pistols and Punk Rockâ€ is important. The Sex Pistols may not have the strongest claim to have invented punk, but in a sense that isnâ€™t as true for other foundational bands, they were punk; their career trajectory; form band, play shows, cause outrage, record demos, cause outrage, sign contracts, appear on TV, cause outrage, get dumped by label, cause outrage get banned from venues, release singles, cause outrage, release album, cause outrage, split up, have a member die â€“ within the space of around two years, is a microcosm of UK punk. The British punk scene was born with them and it essentially died with Sid Vicious; everything thereafter is either post-punk, second-wave punk or pastiche. Whether embodying a movement is an achievement as such is hard to say and in a way doesnâ€™t matter, but what Savage documents is the way in which a youth movement â€“ one with many and varied influences and antecedents â€“ absorbed and expressed the anxieties of its time and in turn embodied and shaped them.

Away from that book, Iâ€™ll keep up with my pick of the most interesting things to be sent my way in February.

Out in April is a reissue of a noise-rock classic from 1995:

Caspar BrÃ¶tzmann Massaker

Home

Southern Lord Recordings

Sounding something like The Birthday Party playing noisy free jazz, the Massaker are a brutal guitar-bass-drums (with minimalist vocals) trio; heavy on feedback, tense dynamics and churning distortion, but sometimes almost groovy and (very) occasionally kind of pretty. Home was their fifth album and itâ€™s pretty similar to the only other one of their albums that I know, The Tribe, from 1987. Squally, angular and dark but with insistent percussion, itâ€™s a great palate-cleanser for your ears after too much pop music.

I could say the same about this, very different but equally eccentric record:

JZ Replacement

Disrespectful

Rainy Days Records

Zhenya Strigalev (saxophone), Jamie Murray (drums) and Tim Lefebvre (bass) have made a frankly insane-sounding but weirdly addictive record that at different times reminds me of the John Zorn/Bil Laswell/Mick Harris jazz/grind band Painkiller, Ornette Coleman and King Tubby. But it also has the odd moment of funk, breakbeat and drum-n-bass. Nevertheless itâ€™s amazingly coherent and although at times I thought Murray, Strigalev or Lefebvre was what made it so great, subtracting any one element would make it all collapse. Recording something at once as familiar and peculiar as any song here (â€˜Guilty Look 3â€˜ is a great example) is a special skill. Disrespectful borrows from everywhere and yet somehow sounds like nothing else â€“ and really thatâ€™s just what jazz is all about.

Perchta

UfÃ¥ng

Prophecy Productions
